pr_title: Fix parent/child issues with inferred spans

timeline.message:
Fix parent/child issues with inferred spans

Inferred spans can track a list of child or successor ids
With transitive reduction, the UI can then make regular spans a child of inferred spans

Add tests, set default capacity to 16

This capacity seems to be the most effective in the benchmarks
But it's going to depend a lot on the application
16 still seems like a good default.
It grows much quicker if the actual capacity is high
but still does not seem wasteful for lower capacity needs.
It's also the default for lists in the JDK
Serialize successor_ids as hex string as opposed to a long

Rename successor_ids to child_ids

- Add changelog
- Adjust known issues documentation

timeline.bodyHTML:
Suggested change
* @see co.elastic.apm.agent.impl.transaction.Span#childIds
* @see co.elastic.apm.agent.impl.transaction.AbstractSpan#childIds
timeline.author: eyalkoren
eyalkoren

replies.bodyText:
Not really. Lists are quite tricky to pool as they can have vastly different sizes. The danger is that over time, all lists in the pool will be quite large even though there are only few that actually contain a lot of elements.
Judging from the benchmarks, the allocations caused by the inferred spans processing increase by 10%. That seems reasonable and it's definitely not the major source of allocations.
replies.author: felixbarny

Suggested change
" bbbb b ",
" a aaaa aa a a ",

" bbbb b ",
" a aaaa a a a ",
"1 2 2 3 3 1"

Just to make sure that one measurement is enough
timeline.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText: Hm, that doesn't work because b is still considered the top of the stack at the time 3 gets activated.
replies.author: felixbarny

replies.bodyText: Why isn't that enough, if you know that activation of 3 happens after deactivation of 2 and you know that b cannot be a (direct or indirect) child of 3?
replies.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText:
Because of situations like these:
 aa  aa 
1  22  1

We have to add each activation to the childIds of the current top of the stack.
However, it leads to errors in situations like these:
 bbb      
 aaa aa a 
1   2  2 1

As 2 is falsely declared a child of b when it's actually a child of a. Currently not sure how to fix it without introducing regressions.
replies.author: felixbarny

replies.bodyText: I think I've managed to fix it
replies.author: felixbarny

timeline.author: eyalkoren

timeline.body: How come `2` is not a child of `a`?
timeline.bodyText: How come 2 is not a child of a?
timeline.bodyHTML: How come 2 is not a child of a?
timeline.author: eyalkoren
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -266,29 +272,181 @@ void testDeactivationBeforeEnd() throws Exception {
     }
 
     /*
-     * [1            ]    [1            ]
-     *  [a          ]      [a          ]
-     *   [2   ]  [3]        [b    ] [3]   <- b is supposed to stealChildIdsFom(a)
-     *    [b   ]            [2   ]           however, it should only steal 2, not 3
+     * [1           ]    [1           ]
+     *  [a         ]      [a         ]
+     *   [2   ] [3]        [b    ][3]   <- b is supposed to stealChildIdsFom(a)
+     *    [b   ]           [2   ]          however, it should only steal 2, not 3
      */
     @Test
     void testDectivationBeforeEnd2() throws Exception {
         assertCallTree(new String[]{
-            "   bbbb b      ",
-            " a aaaa aa a a ",
-            "1 2    2  3 3 1"
+            "   bbbb b     ",
+            " a aaaa a a a ",
+            "1 2    2 3 3 1"
         }, new Object[][] {
-            {"a",       9},
+            {"a",       8},
             {"  b",     5},
         }, new Object[][] {
-            {"1",       14},
-            {"  a",     12},
+            {"1",       13},
+            {"  a",     11},
             {"    b",    6},
             {"      2",  5},
             {"    3",    2},
         });
     }
 
+    /*
+     * [1       ]
+     *  [a     ]
+     *   [b][2]
+     */

+            " bbb      ",
+            " aaa aa a ",
+            "1   2  2 1"

+            {"a",       6},

+            {"1",       9},

+    }
+
+    /*
+     * [1         ]
+     *  [a][2    ]
+     *  [b] [3  ]
+     *       [c]
+     */
+    @Test
+    void testNestedActivationAfterMethodEnds() throws Exception {
+        Map<String, AbstractSpan<?>> spans = assertCallTree(new String[]{
+            " bbb        ",
+            " aaa  ccc   ",
+            "1   23   321"

+            {"  b",      2, List.of("a")},
+            {"  2",      6},
+            {"    3",    4},
+            {"      c",  2}
+        });
+        assertThat(spans.get("b").getChildIds().getSize()).isEqualTo(0);
+    }
+
+    /*
+     * [1           ]

+     *  [b  ] [4  ]
+     *   [2]   [c]

+    @Test
+    void testRegularActivationFollowedByNestedActivationAfterMethodEnds() throws Exception {
+        assertCallTree(new String[]{

+            " b b b        ",
+            " a a a  ccc   ",
+            "1 2 2 34   431"

+            {"  b",      3},

+            {"      c",  2}

replies.bodyText:
Wow, good catch! From now on, I call you the eagle eye. Or maybe Eyeal 🤔
Submitting fix shortly that searches for common ancestors, instead of always adding the child_ids on the top of the stack
replies.author: felixbarny

timeline.message: Search for common ancestors instead of adding to top of stack

timeline.body: This might be problematic for the UI: https://github.com/elastic/kibana/issues/62952#issuecomment-624472852
timeline.bodyText: This might be problematic for the UI: elastic/kibana#62952 (comment)
timeline.bodyHTML: This might be problematic for the UI: elastic/kibana#62952 (comment)
timeline.author: felixbarny

timeline.message:
Fix test

- speed up stealActiveChildIds by adding a set of active spans

Fix more edge cases

- Adds internal profiling_inferred_spans_backup_diagnostic_files option
- Adds SamplingProfilerReplay to diagnose issues when creating inferred spans
